trends.name: 4K/8K Camera Resolution Migration
trends.description: ADAS cameras are rapidly advancing from 1-2 megapixel sensors to 4K (8MP) and emerging 8K (33MP) resolutions. This enables better object detection at longer distances, improved lane marking recognition, and more precise depth perception for autonomous features.
trends.silicon_implication: Requires image signal processors with 4-10x higher bandwidth and specialized AI acceleration for real-time processing.

evidence.key_quote: High-resolution cameras (4K+) will represent 60% of ADAS camera shipments by 2027, driven by L3+ automation requirements

trends.name: Radar Frequency Migration to 77-81 GHz
trends.description: Automotive radar is consolidating around the 77-81 GHz frequency band, abandoning older 24 GHz systems. This higher frequency provides better resolution for detecting smaller objects and enables more compact antenna designs for integration into vehicle bodies.
trends.silicon_implication: Demands advanced RF semiconductor processes (BiCMOS, SiGe) with precise millimeter-wave circuit design.

evidence.key_quote: 77-81 GHz radar adoption will reach 95% of new ADAS installations by 2026, replacing legacy 24 GHz systems

trends.name: Centralized Compute Architecture Shift
trends.description: Vehicle manufacturers are moving from distributed processing (separate chips for each sensor) to centralized domain controllers that process data from multiple cameras, radars, and other sensors in one powerful computer. This reduces wiring complexity and enables better sensor fusion.
trends.silicon_implication: Creates demand for high-performance automotive SoCs with 100+ TOPS AI processing and multiple high-speed interfaces.

evidence.key_quote: Our Hardware 4.0 processes input from 8 cameras and 12 sensors on a single 144 TOPS chip, replacing previous distributed architecture

trends.name: Transformer Neural Network Adoption
trends.description: ADAS systems are adopting transformer-based AI models (similar to ChatGPT architecture) for better understanding of complex driving scenarios. These models excel at processing sequential data from multiple sensors and predicting driver/pedestrian behavior.
trends.silicon_implication: Requires specialized AI accelerators optimized for attention mechanisms and large matrix operations.

evidence.key_quote: Transformer models improve object detection accuracy by 23% over CNNs but require 5x more computational resources

trends.name: ISO 26262 ASIL-D Safety Requirements
trends.description: As ADAS features become more critical to vehicle safety (like automated emergency braking), they must meet the highest automotive safety standard (ASIL-D). This requires redundant systems, extensive self-monitoring, and fail-safe operation modes.
trends.silicon_implication: Mandates dual-core processors, hardware safety monitors, and specialized safety-certified manufacturing processes.

evidence.key_quote: ASIL-D certified ADAS processors command 40% price premiums but are required for 70% of L3+ automation functions

trends.name: Sub-6W Power Budget Constraints
trends.description: Electric vehicles demand ultra-low power ADAS systems to preserve battery range. The industry target is keeping total ADAS power consumption under 6 watts while maintaining high performance for safety-critical functions.
trends.silicon_implication: Drives adoption of advanced 5nm/3nm process nodes and specialized low-power circuit design techniques.

evidence.key_quote: Our next-generation ADAS system targets 5.5W total power consumption while delivering 200 TOPS performance

trends.name: Cost Pressure for Mass Market Adoption
trends.description: ADAS features are expanding beyond luxury vehicles to mainstream cars under $30,000. This requires dramatic cost reduction in semiconductor content while maintaining safety and performance standards.
trends.silicon_implication: Necessitates system-on-chip integration, shared processing resources, and migration to mature process nodes.

evidence.source: IHS Markit Automotive Electronics Cost Analysis 2024
evidence.key_quote: ADAS semiconductor content must decrease from $400 to under $200 per vehicle to enable mass market L2+ features

acronyms.ADAS: Advanced Driver Assistance Systems - technologies that help drivers with safety and convenience features
acronyms.ASIL-D: Automotive Safety Integrity Level D - the highest automotive safety standard for life-critical systems
acronyms.TOPS: Tera Operations Per Second - measure of AI processing performance (1 TOPS = 1 trillion calculations/second)
acronyms.SoC: System-on-Chip - a single semiconductor chip containing multiple processing functions
acronyms.BiCMOS: Bipolar Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor - advanced chip manufacturing process for RF applications
acronyms.SiGe: Silicon-Germanium - semiconductor material used for high-frequency radio applications
acronyms.CNN: Convolutional Neural Network - traditional AI model architecture for image processing
